title: # Other expenses: entertainment expenses: disallowance under Section 356 ITEPA 2003: steps to follow

details.body:
# Other expenses: entertainment expenses: disallowance under Section 356 ITEPA 2003: steps to follow

Step 1Decide if the employer is carrying on a trade, business, profession or vocation (see [EIM32575](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32575))If the answer is no, Section 356 does not apply. You can consider the employee’s request for an expenses deduction using the general rule for employees’ expenses in Section 336 ITEPA 2003 (see [EIM32615](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32615) onwards). If the answer is yes, go on to Step 2. Step 2Decide if the expenditure relates to the provision of entertainment, or a gift (see [EIM32580](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32580.htm))If the answer is no, Section 356 does not apply. You can consider the employee’s request for an expenses deduction using the general rule for employees’ expenses in Section 336 (see [EIM32615](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32615) onwards). If the answer is yes, go on to Step 3. Step 3Decide if the case falls within the exceptions set out in [EIM32585](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32585.htm)If it does, Section 356 does not apply. You can consider the employee’s request for an expenses deduction using the general rule for employees’ expenses in Section 336 (see [EIM32615](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM32615) onwards). If it does not, Section 356 applies and no deduction is due even if the expenses would have satisfied the rule in Section 336.
